The files (classes) listed below improperly resolve hostname when endpoint identification is enabled but an SSL socket is not created with an explicit hostname (which is the case with `HttpsURLConnection`). deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The Apache `commons-collections` packages are vulnerable to a Denial of Service (DoS) attack. The `add()` method of the `SetUniqueList` class mishandles the order of operations when invoking its parent `List` implementation. Consequently, adding an instance of itself results in infinite recursion and deviates from the behavior defined by the standard JRE `List` contract. A remote attacker who can cause an application to add `SetUniqueList` instances to themselves can exploit this vulnerability to crash the affected application with a `StackOverflowError` exception.

deeperData.description: Bouncy Castle For Java before 1.74 is affected by an LDAP injection vulnerability. The vulnerability only affects applications that use an LDAP CertStore from Bouncy Castle to validate X.509 certificates. During the certificate validation process, Bouncy Castle inserts the certificate's Subject Name into an LDAP search filter without any escaping, which leads to an LDAP injection vulnerability.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: Bouncy Castle is vulnerable to LDAP Injection attacks due to Improper Certificate Validation. The `parseDN()` method of the `X509LDAPCertStoreSpi` class propagates X.509 certificate subject names to an LDAP search filter without proper sanitization. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by supplying a certificate with a subject name that contains LDAP-related metacharacters. Execution of the modified query may expose the attacker to sensitive information contained within the application's LDAP CertStore.

deeperData.description: Bouncy Castle for Java before 1.73 contains a potential Denial of Service (DoS) issue within the Bouncy Castle org.bouncycastle.openssl.PEMParser class. This class parses OpenSSL PEM encoded streams containing X.509 certificates, PKCS8 encoded keys, and PKCS7 objects. Parsing a file that has crafted ASN.1 data through the PEMParser causes an OutOfMemoryError, which can enable a denial of service attack. (For users of the FIPS Java API: BC-FJA 1.0.2.3 and earlier are affected; BC-FJA 1.0.2.4 is fixed.)

A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by supplying crafted ASN.1 data via PEM-encoded streams. Consuming such data may crash affected applications with an `OutOfMemoryError`.

deeperData.description: An issue was discovered in ECCurve.java and ECCurve.cs in Bouncy Castle Java (BC Java) before 1.78, BC Java LTS before 2.73.6, BC-FJA before 1.0.2.5, and BC C# .Net before 2.3.1. deeperData.explanationMarkdown:

The `solveQuadraticEquation()` method of the `ECCurve$AbstractF2m` class does not properly validate  `F2m` parameters when importing a digital certificate containing Elliptic Curve (EC) keys. Parsing such certificate may increase CPU usage potentially leading to a crash in the affected system.

deeperData.description: An issue was discovered in Bouncy Castle Java TLS API and JSSE Provider before 1.78. Timing-based leakage may occur in RSA based handshakes because of exception processing.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
Multiple `bouncycastle` components as vulnerable to a Timing Attack ("a timing variant of Bleichenbacher called Marvin Attack"). The `safeDecryptPreMasterSecret()` method in the `BcDefaultTlsCredentialedDecryptor.class` file when calling operations from `TlsRsaKeyExchange.class` induces an observable timing discrepancy depending on the output of the RSA algorithm. An attacker could exploit this flaw to potentially deduce the secrets based on the exceptions that occur during the decryption workflow.

**Note:** This vulnerability is also tracked as [CVE-2024-20952](https://github.com/bcgit/bc-java/issues/1528#issuecomment-1896674881) in Oracle products such as Java.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `bouncycastle` package is vulnerable due to Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm. The `configure()` method in `BC.class` allows the use of BKS-V1 keystores, which employ a cryptographically weak HMAC hashing algorithm. As a result, a local attacker could tamper with the keystore files of an application using BKS-V1.

*NOTE: This issue is distinct from CVE-2018-5382, which was filed as a result of an incorrect HMAC calculation that is the cause of the weakness in BKS-V1 described above. That issue was fixed in* `bouncycastle` *version 1.47 with the introduction of BKS-V2. BKS-V1 was reimplemented in version 1.49 in order to support certain legacy devices and applications.*
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component if BKS-V1 keystores are used.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
Either upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue or avoiding the use of BKS-V1 keystores will mitigate this issue. In either case, any previously generated BKS-V1 keystores should be regenerated using BKS-V2.

deeperData.description:
Loop with Unreachable Exit Condition ('Infinite Loop') vulnerability in Apache Commons Compress.This issue affects Apache Commons Compress: from 1.3 through 1.25.0.

Users are recommended to upgrade to version 1.26.0 which fixes the issue.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `commons-compress` package is vulnerable to Denial of Service (DoS) attacks due to an Infinite Loop. The `resetBlockSize()` method of the `TapeInputStream` class processes Unix `dump` archive files without validating the compression block size. A local attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a crafted `dump` file containing malformed or corrupt metadata indicating a block size of 0 or less, resulting in an infinite loop and a DoS condition. Under some circumstances, it may be possible for the attacker to leverage this vulnerability to execute arbitrary code.

***Advisory Deviation Notice***:
The Sonatype Security Research team has created a CVSS score that differs from the publicly available score that, based on our research, more accurately reflects the severity of the vulnerability.

Users are recommended to upgrade to version 1.26, which fixes the issue.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:

The methods and files listed below, when unpacking Pack200 archives and parsing numerical values associated with the archive's attributes, fail to appropriately handle erroneous or invalid values. This can cause improper resource allocation in some cases, resulting in Out of Memory exceptions and ultimately application crashes.

    - `protected void firePropertyChange(final String propertyName, final Object oldValue, final Object newValue)`
  - org/apache/commons/compress/harmony/unpack200/NewAttributeBands.class
    - `private Integer readNumber(final StringReader stream) throws IOException`

deeperData.description: Jenkins 2.318 and earlier, LTS 2.303.2 and earlier does not check agent-to-controller access to create parent directories in FilePath#mkdirs.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `jenkins-core` package is vulnerable to a Missing Authorization condition. The `mkdirs()` method in the `SoloFilePathFilter` class fails to ensure that all of the parent directories of the directory about to be created should be writeable by the agent process copying the build files that will be utilized by the agent. This allows malicious attackers the ability to manipulate agents into writing arbitrary files onto the Jenkins system outside of the intended build directories, leading to Arbitrary File Write. Sensitive data may be corrupted or modified due to this vulnerability.

deeperData.description: File path filters in the agent-to-controller security subsystem of Jenkins 2.318 and earlier, LTS 2.303.2 and earlier do not canonicalize paths, allowing operations to follow symbolic links to outside allowed directories.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `jenkins-core` package is vulnerable to Link Following. The `checkFileAccess()` method in the `FilePathRuleConfig` class does not canonicalize file paths, thereby allowing symbolic links to be followed outside of allowed directories. A remote attacker can exploit this behavior by submitting a specially-crafted request to read and write arbitrary files on the Jenkins controller file system.

deeperData.description: Jenkins 2.318 and earlier, LTS 2.303.2 and earlier does not check agent-to-controller access to create symbolic links when unarchiving a symbolic link in FilePath#untar.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `jenkins-core` packages is vulnerable to a Missing Authorization condition. The `readFromTar()` method utilized by the `untar()` method in the `FilePath` class fails to check that symbolic links existing inside of a tar archive that is being decompressed can be written to the host system and inside the intended directory. A remote attacker with control over the input tar archive being decompressed may craft a malicious archive that contains symbolic links that could lead to Arbitrary File Read when written to locations where a Jenkins Build Agent is not allowed to create symbolic links.

deeperData.description: The agent-to-controller security check FilePath#reading(FileVisitor) in Jenkins 2.318 and earlier, LTS 2.303.2 and earlier does not reject any operations, allowing users to have unrestricted read access using certain operations (creating archives, FilePath#copyRecursiveTo).
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `jenkins-core` package is vulnerable to a Missing Authorization condition. The `reading()` method in the `FilePath` class fails to reject build agent operations that attempt to access unauthorized locations during file reads on the Jenkins server's filesystem. By allowing the `Remoting` Jenkins API unrestricted access to operations that require reading files from the host system, a remote attacker may craft archives that could cause a  build agent to read any file on the host's filesystem. This is effectively an Arbitrary File Read vulnerability and leads to Sensitive Information Disclosure.

deeperData.description: Agent processes are able to completely bypass file path filtering by wrapping the file operation in an agent file path in Jenkins 2.318 and earlier, LTS 2.303.2 and earlier.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `jenkins-core` package is vulnerable to a Protection Mechanism Failure condition. The `checkFileAccess()` method in the `FilePathRuleConfig` class fails to ensure that file paths are normalized prior to checking file path permissions. This causes methods like `FilePath$ReadToString` that are dependent on file path filtering to skip permission checks for Jenkins Agents that specify file paths as an Agent file paths, leading to bypassing the defined protection mechanisms for Jenkins servers. An attacker with control over the file operations requested by a Jenkins Agent can exploit this behaviour to gain access to sensitive files and under certain circumstances, modify sensitive files as well.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `jenkins-core` package is vulnerable due to Missing Authorization. The methods listed below in the `FilePath` class fail to properly verify permissions when agents execute actions on files. An attacker, with access to the related operations, can exploit this vulnerability by submitting specially-crafted requests to get information or alter arbitrary files in the underlying system. 

*Vulnerable Method(s)*:

* toURI()
* hasSymlink()
* absolutize()
* isDescendant()
* getFreeDiskSpace()
* getTotalDiskSpace()
* getUsableDiskSpace()

*Advisory Deviation Notice:* The Sonatype security research team discovered that the vulnerability is present since version 1.396 and thus does not affect all previous releases as the advisory states.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue. If it is not possible, apply the [workaround](https://www.jenkins.io/security/advisory/2021-11-04/#SECURITY-2455) suggested in the advisory.

>If you are unable to immediately upgrade to Jenkins 2.319, LTS 2.303.3, you can install the Remoting Security Workaround Plugin. It will prevent all agent-to-controller file access using FilePath APIs. Because it is more restrictive than Jenkins 2.319, LTS 2.303.3, more plugins are incompatible with it. Make sure to read the plugin documentation before installing it. 

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.description: FilePath#listFiles lists files outside directories that agents are allowed to access when following symbolic links in Jenkins 2.318 and earlier, LTS 2.303.2 and earlier.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `jenkins-core` package is vulnerable due to Missing Authorization. The `noFalse()` method in the `SoloFilePathFilter` class does not properly check user permissions before listing file paths outside allowed directories via the `FilePath#listFiles` endpoint. A remote attacker with agent read access can exploit this behavior by submitting a specially-crafted request containing symbolic links which, when followed, would result in exposure of otherwise restricted data.

deeperData.description: Jenkins 2.318 and earlier, LTS 2.303.2 and earlier does not limit agent read/write access to the libs/ directory inside build directories when using the FilePath APIs, allowing attackers in control of agent processes to replace the code of a trusted library with a modified variant. This results in unsandboxed code execution in the Jenkins controller process.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `jenkins-core` package is vulnerable due to Protection Mechanism Failure. The `filepath-filter.conf` file allows unrestricted agent read/write access to the `libs` directory that is used to store copies of shared libraries by the Pipeline: Shared Groovy Libraries plugin. A remote attacker who can control agent processes can exploit this behavior by replacing a trusted library with a specially-crafted one while using the `FilePath` API, resulting in arbitrary code execution in the Jenkins controller process.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:

*Workaround:* 
>If you are unable to immediately upgrade to Jenkins 2.319, LTS 2.303.3, you can install the [Remoting Security Workaround Plugin](https://plugins.jenkins.io/remoting-security-workaround/). It will prevent all agent-to-controller file access using `FilePath` APIs. Because it is more restrictive than Jenkins 2.319, LTS 2.303.3, more plugins are incompatible with it. Make sure to read the plugin documentation before installing it.

Reference: [https://www.jenkins.io/security/advisory/2021-11-04/#SECURITY-2423](https://www.jenkins.io/security/advisory/2021-11-04/#SECURITY-2423)

deeperData.description: Jenkins 2.318 and earlier, LTS 2.303.2 and earlier allows any agent to read and write the contents of any build directory stored in Jenkins with very few restrictions.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `jenkins-core` package is vulnerable to an Incomplete List of Disallowed Inputs condition. The `FilePath` class and the filters that are utilized to intercept build agent requests that manipulate file paths fail to ensure that agents do not have read and write access to other build directories during a building instance. An attacker with control over an external build agent or source code that is used during the build process may craft malicious file names that would escape the expected build directory to force the build agent to read from or write to any build directory that exists on the system. This leads to Sensitive Information Disclosure and Data Corruption.

deeperData.description: Jenkins 2.333 and earlier, LTS 2.319.2 and earlier defines custom XStream converters that have not been updated to apply the protections for the vulnerability CVE-2021-43859 and allow unconstrained resource usage.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `jenkins-core` package is vulnerable to Denial of Service (DoS) attacks. The `populateCollection()` method of the `RobustCollectionConverter` class and the `putCurrentEntryIntoMap()` method of the `RobustMapConverter` class fail to account for overly recursive XML structures. A remote attacker who can supply an XML file, such as `build.xml` or `config.xml`, to affected Jenkins instances can exploit this vulnerability to cause the instances to crash due to excessive consumption of available resources.

deeperData.description: A cross-site request forgery (CSRF) vulnerability in Jenkins 2.329 and earlier, LTS 2.319.1 and earlier allows attackers to trigger build of job without parameters when no security realm is set.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `jenkins-core` package is vulnerable to Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) attacks. The `checkPermission()` method of the `BuildAuthorizationToken` fails to perform when no security realm is set. Consequently, because this method enforces POST requests, users within such environments can issue GET requests to `/build`. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability to execute builds, albeit with no parameters, by enticing users of affected Jenkins instances into submitting crafted requests.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `jenkins-core` package contains an Observable Timing Discrepancy vulnerability. The `authenticate2()` method in the `HudsonPrivateSecurityRealm` class takes a different amount of time on login attempts with valid versus invalid usernames. A remote attacker can abuse this behavior to identify the existence of users via username enumeration.

deeperData.description: Jenkins 2.270 through 2.393 (both inclusive), LTS 2.277.1 through 2.375.3 (both inclusive) does not escape the Jenkins version a plugin depends on when rendering the error message stating its incompatibility with the current version of Jenkins, resulting in a stored cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability exploitable by attackers able to provide plugins to the configured update sites and have this message shown by Jenkins instances.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `jenkins-core` package is vulnerable to Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks. The `doPluginsSearch` function in the `PluginManager` class does not properly sanitize the minimum required Jenkins version field when viewing a plugin inside the plugin manager feature. This attribute is used to show an error message when an incompatible version of Jenkins is installed. A remote attacker can exploit this behavior by adding a manipulated core dependency with malicious JavaScript inside the version field, resulting in a stored script execution when the warning is rendered on the victim's browser.

deeperData.description: Jenkins 2.393 and earlier, LTS 2.375.3 and earlier creates a temporary file in the default temporary directory with the default permissions for newly created files when uploading a plugin for installation, potentially allowing attackers with access to the Jenkins controller file system to read and write the file before it is used, potentially resulting in arbitrary code execution.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `jenkins-core` package is vulnerable due to the Creation of Temporary Files With Insecure Permissions. The `doUploadPlugin()` function in the `PluginManager` class allows the creation of temporary files with default permissions that may provide read and write access to all system users. deeperData.description: Jenkins 2.393 and earlier, LTS 2.375.3 and earlier uses the Apache Commons FileUpload library without specifying limits for the number of request parts introduced in version 1.5 for CVE-2023-24998 in hudson.util.MultipartFormDataParser, allowing attackers to trigger a denial of service.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
Jenkins is vulnerable to Denial of Service (DoS) attacks. The constructor method in the `MultipartFormDataParser` class fails to limit the number of files permitted in a multipart upload forcing Jenkins to consume excessive resources. A remote attacker with the ability to upload files can exploit this vulnerability by submitting a large multipart form request to the endpoint processing file uploads. This will exhaust system resources and ultimately result in a DoS condition. 

*Advisory Deviation Notice:*
                        The Sonatype Security Research team has created a CVSS score that differs from the publicly available score that, based on our research, more accurately reflects the severity of the vulnerability.

deeperData.description: Jenkins 2.393 and earlier, LTS 2.375.3 and earlier shows temporary directories related to job workspaces, which allows attackers with Item/Workspace permission to access their contents.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `jenkins-core` package is vulnerable to Information Disclosure. The `newInputStreamDenyingSymlinkAsNeeded()` method of the `FilePath` class, the `serveFile()` method of the `DirectoryBrowserSupport` class, and the `DirectoryBrowserSupport/dir.jelly` file expose build-related temporary files to Item/Workspace users viewing job workspaces. A remote attacker with the aforementioned permissions can exploit this vulnerability to obtain sensitive information, such as credentials, that may be leveraged to perform further attacks.

**Note**: This vulnerability exists due to an insufficient fix for [CVE-2021-21602](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-21602) in versions `2.275` and `2.263.2`.

deeperData.description: In Jenkins 2.399 and earlier, LTS 2.387.3 and earlier, POST requests are sent in order to load the list of context actions. If part of the URL includes insufficiently escaped user-provided values, a victim may be tricked into sending a POST request to an unexpected endpoint by opening a context menu.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `jenkins-core` package is vulnerable to Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) attacks. The `invokeContextMenu()` function in `breadcrumbs.js` issues POST requests to URLs constructed from the provided `contextMenuUrl` argument. A remote attacker with `Item/Configure` permissions can exploit this vulnerability with certain insufficiently sanitized elements, such as label expressions, and crafted URLs. This will result in POST requests to unexpected endpoints when other Jenkins users click the affected context menu.

***Advisory Deviation Notice***:
The Sonatype Security Research team discovered that this vulnerability was introduced in version `1.513` and therefore does not affect all versions `2.399`, `LTS 2.387.3`, and earlier as stated in the advisory.

The `fitsSearchBuildVariables()` method of the `HistoryPageFilter` class allows users to filter build queries using sensitive fields when using the search function of the Build History Widget. A remote attacker with sufficient permissions take advantage of this behavior by leveraging search filters on sensitive fields to systematically test various string combinations. This could potentially enable brute force attacks on sensitive build variables, such as passwords.

deeperData.description: Jenkins 2.423 and earlier, LTS 2.414.1 and earlier creates a temporary file in the system temporary directory with the default permissions for newly created files when installing a plugin from a URL, potentially allowing attackers with access to the system temporary directory to replace the file before it is installed in Jenkins, potentially resulting in arbitrary code execution.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `jenkins-core` package is vulnerable due to Creation of Temporary File With Insecure Permissions. The `doUploadPlugin()` method of the `PluginManager` class creates temporary plugin files in the system's default temporary directory when installing a plugin from a URL. A local attacker with access to the system's temporary directory can take advantage of this behavior by modifying the plugin files before they are used. These modified plugins can be used to execute arbitrary code or induce other unexpected behavior on the target machine.

*Advisory Deviation Notice:*
                        The Sonatype Security Research team discovered that this vulnerability was actually introduced in version v1.509.3 instead of affecting all versions prior to v2.423 and LTS v2.414.1 as stated in the advisory. The Sonatype Security Research team has also created a CVSS score that differs from the publicly available score that, based on our research, more accurately reflects the severity of the vulnerability.

When processing files files uploaded via the Stapler web framework and the Jenkins API, the constructor of the `MultipartFormDataParser` class creates temporary files in the system's default temporary directory with the default permissions for newly created files. deeperData.description: Jenkins 2.441 and earlier, LTS 2.426.2 and earlier does not disable a feature of its CLI command parser that replaces an '@' character followed by a file path in an argument with the file's contents, allowing unauthenticated attackers to read arbitrary files on the Jenkins controller file system.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `jenkins-core` package contains an Arbitrary File Read vulnerability. The `getCmdLineParser()` method of the `CLICommand` class utilizes the `args4j` library to parse command arguments and options on the Jenkins controller. This command parser is configured by default to replace `@` characters followed by a file path in an argument with the file's contents. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability to read arbitrary files on the vulnerable system using the default character encoding of the Jenkins controller process. The contents of such files may be leveraged by the attacker to perform Remote Code Execution (RCE) under certain conditions.

deeperData.description: Jenkins 2.217 through 2.441 (both inclusive), LTS 2.222.1 through 2.426.2 (both inclusive) does not perform origin validation of requests made through the CLI WebSocket endpoint, resulting in a cross-site WebSocket hijacking (CSWSH) vulnerability, allowing attackers to execute CLI commands on the Jenkins controller.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `jenkins-core` package is vulnerable to Cross-Site WebSocket Hijacking. The `doWs()` method of the `CLIAction` class executes CLI commands, received via WebSocket requests, on the Jenkins controller without validating the origin of those requests. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by forging requests from a legitimate user, either via enticing the user to click a crafted link or by visiting a malicious website that sends crafted requests via an embedded script, allowing them to indirectly interact with the Jenkins controller. Depending on how the browser used by the victim handles cross-origin requests, this could lead to Remote Code Execution (RCE).

***Advisory Deviation Notice***:
The Sonatype Security Research team discovered that this vulnerability was actually introduced in version 2.216 as opposed to version 2.217 as stated in the advisory.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue. Alternatively, the project suggests the following workarounds:

>__Disable CLI access__
>Disabling access to the CLI will prevent exploitation completely and is the __recommended workaround__ for administrators unable to immediately update. Applying this workaround does not require a Jenkins restart. For instructions, see the [documentation for this workaround](https://github.com/jenkinsci-cert/SECURITY-3314-3315/).
>
>__Prevent WebSocket access using a reverse proxy__
>If Jenkins is accessible only through a reverse proxy, configure that proxy to prevent access to the CLI via WebSocket by not upgrading requests.

Reference: [https://www.jenkins.io/security/advisory/2024-01-24/#SECURITY-3315](https://www.jenkins.io/security/advisory/2024-01-24/#SECURITY-3315)

deeperData.description: Jenkins 2.470 and earlier, LTS 2.452.3 and earlier does not perform a permission check in an HTTP endpoint, allowing attackers with Overall/Read permission to access other users' "My Views".
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `org.jenkins-ci.main:jenkins-core` package is vulnerable due to an Incorrect Authorization. The `MyViewsProperty` class fails to properly restrict users with Overall/Read permission from accessing other users' `My Views` and users with View/Configure and View/Delete permissions from modifying them. An authenticated remote attacker holding the aforementioned permissions can abuse this vulnerability to access and change data in other users' `My Views`.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The Apache HttpComponents project, a library of low level Java components focused on HTTP and associated protocols, is vulnerable to a Denial of Service (DoS). The `HttpParser` class' `readRawLine` method performs unbound reads on HTTP POST data. If a new line character `\n` is not encountered, memory consumption is not limited, leading to a Denial of Service.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue. 

*NOTE:* Component `commons-httpclient:commons-httpclient` is not expected to have any further releases, including a fixed version. The component was relocated to `org.apache.httpcomponents:httpclient`. Therefore, users of the affected versions of `commons-httpclient:commons-httpclient` should consider upgrading to a non-vulnerable version of `org.apache.httpcomponents:httpclient`.

deeperData.description: Unbounded memory allocation in Google Guava 11.0 through 24.x before 24.1.1 allows remote attackers to conduct denial of service attacks against servers that depend on this library and deserialize attacker-provided data, because the AtomicDoubleArray class (when serialized with Java serialization) and the CompoundOrdering class (when serialized with GWT serialization) perform eager allocation without appropriate checks on what a client has sent and whether the data size is reasonable.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
Guava is vulnerable to Denial of Service (DoS). When untrusted input is supplied to the `AtomicDoubleArray` and `CompoundOrdering` classes, it is possible for an attacker to specify a large integer number as part of that untrusted input.  This untrusted integer `n` is used to allocate an array of length `n`.  Thus with large values of `n`, it is possible to cause an application to run out of memory.

Advisory Deviation Notice: The Sonatype security research team discovered that the fix for this vulnerability was actually introduced in version 23.6.1 for 23.6.x instead of 24.1.1 as stated in https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2018-10237
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component if it uses Java deserialization or GWT-RPC to deserialize untrusted data.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

deeperData.description:
Use of Java's default temporary directory for file creation in `FileBackedOutputStream` in Google Guava versions 1.0 to 31.1 on Unix systems and Android Ice Cream Sandwich allows other users and apps on the machine with access to the default Java temporary directory to be able to access the files created by the class.

Even though the security vulnerability is fixed in version 32.0.0, we recommend using version 32.0.1 as version 32.0.0 breaks some functionality under Windows.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `guava` package is vulnerable due to the Creation of Temporary Files With Insecure Permissions. The `update()` method of the `FileBackedOutputStream` class and the `createTempDir()` method of the `Files` class create temporary files with world-readable permissions. An attacker with access to this package's temporary file storage locations can exploit this vulnerability to exfiltrate information that may be leveraged to perform further attacks against affected applications.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.

In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `guava` package contains an Improper Authorization vulnerability. The `createTempDir()` method in the `Files` class creates a temporary directory with insecure default permissions. A local attacker can leverage this behavior to access otherwise-restricted directories created by the affected method. This access may allow the attacker to obtain sensitive information that may be used for further attacks.

Note: This vulnerability has since been given the identifier CVE-2020-8908.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using the `Files.createTempDir()` method of this component to create directories.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `trilead-ssh2` package is vulnerable to Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks. This project downloads dependencies over HTTP due to an insecure repository configuration within the `.pom` file. Consequently, a MitM could intercept requests to the specified repository and replace the requested dependencies with malicious versions, which can execute arbitrary code from the application that was built with them.

deeperData.description: Jenkins WMI Windows Agents Plugin 1.8 and earlier includes the Windows Remote Command library which has a buffer overflow vulnerability that may allow users able to connect to a named pipe to execute commands on the Windows agent machine.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `WMI Windows Agents` Jenkins Plugin is vulnerable to Remote Command Execution due to an OS Command Injection vulnerability. The `launch` method in the `ManagedWindowsServiceLauncher` class uses the `Windows Remote Command` library which has a buffer overflow vulnerability. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability to send a specially-crafted hostname to execute commands on the Windows agent machine when the `javaPath` environment has an invalid or non-existing path.

deeperData.description: Jenkins WMI Windows Agents Plugin 1.8 and earlier includes the Windows Remote Command library does not implement access control, potentially allowing users to start processes even if they're not allowed to log in.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `WMI Windows Agents` Jenkins Plugin contains a Missing Authorization vulnerability. The `launch` method in the `ManagedWindowsServiceLauncher` class does not perform an Authorization check prior to initiating the Windows Remote Command library. An unauthorized attacker can exploit this vulnerability to start processes they would otherwise not have access to.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `jnr-posix` package contains a Use After Free vulnerability. The `Open()` and `act()` methods in the `SpawnFileAction$Open` class do not properly copy file `path` buffers that are passed to `posix_spawn_file_actions_addopen()`. This method causes the file named by the path to be opened when a new process is spawned via the `posix_spawn()` call. A context-dependent attacker can exploit this behavior by supplying a specially-crafted path to deallocate the buffer before the `posix_spawn()` operation is completed, to cause an application crash, execute arbitrary code or trigger other unintended behavior.

*Note:* This vulnerability exists because CVE-2014-4043 was not addressed by RHEL.

Reference: 
- [https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1109263#c3](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1109263#c3)
- [https://github.com/jnr/jnr-posix/issues/170](https://github.com/jnr/jnr-posix/issues/170)

deeperData.description: Apache Groovy provides extension methods to aid with creating temporary directories. Prior to this fix, Groovy's implementation of those extension methods was using a now superseded Java JDK method call that is potentially not secure on some operating systems in some contexts. Users not using the extension methods mentioned in the advisory are not affected, but may wish to read the advisory for further details. Versions Affected: 2.0 to 2.4.20, 2.5.0 to 2.5.13, 3.0.0 to 3.0.6, and 4.0.0-alpha-1. Fixed in versions 2.4.21, 2.5.14, 3.0.7, 4.0.0-alpha-2.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
Apache Groovy is vulnerable due to Creation of Temporary File in Directory with Insecure Permissions. The `createTempDir()` method in the `DefaultGroovyStaticMethods.class` unsafely creates temporary directories within the operating system's temporary directory which is shared by all users on a system. An attacker can leverage this behavior to gain unauthorized access to sensitive information or carry out privilege escalation on an affected system.

*Advisory Deviation Notice:* The Sonatype security research team discovered that the root cause of the vulnerability is in 1.1-rc-1, not in 2.0.0 as the advisory states. Additionally, the vulnerability is present in versions 2.6.0-alpha-1 to 3.0.6, not just 3.0.0 before 3.0.7 as the advisory states.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

*Workaround:* 
> Setting the `java.io.tmpdir` system environment variable to a directory that is exclusively owned by the executing user will fix this vulnerability for all operating systems and all Groovy versions.
>
> Users who cannot easily move to the fixed Groovy versions may wish to consider using the JDK's Files#createTempDirectory method instead of the Groovy extension methods.

Reference: [https://groovy-lang.org/security.html#CVE-2020-17521](https://groovy-lang.org/security.html#CVE-2020-17521)

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. deeperData.description: n Spring Framework versions 5.3.0 - 5.3.16 and older unsupported versions, it is possible for a user to provide a specially crafted SpEL expression that may cause a denial of service condition.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `spring-expression` package is vulnerable to a Denial of Service (DoS) attack. The `createArray()` method in the `ConstructorReference` class fails to limit the number of elements in arrays constructed from SpEL expressions. A remote attacker who can supply a SpEL expression can exploit this vulnerability to cause an `OutOfMemoryError` and ultimately a DoS condition.

deeperData.description: In Spring Framework versions 6.0.0 - 6.0.6, 5.3.0 - 5.3.25, 5.2.0.RELEASE - 5.2.22.RELEASE, and older unsupported versions, it is possible for a user to provide a specially crafted SpEL expression that may cause a denial-of-service (DoS) condition.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `spring-expression` package is vulnerable to Denial of Service (DoS) attacks. The `getValueInternal()` methods in the `OperatorMatches` and `OpMultiply` classes fail to limit the input taken and results produced, respectively, by their SpEL operations. The `matches` operation does not restrict the length of user-supplied regular expressions,  while the `multiply` operation does not restrict its resulting text when provided with excessive repeats. A remote attacker who can supply crafted SpEL expressions can leverage these vulnerable operations to cause the application to exhaust its available system resources.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `spring-expression` package is vulnerable to Denial of Service (DoS) attacks. The `doParseExpression()` method in the `InternalSpelExpressionParser` class fails to limit the length of SpEL expressions before attempting to parse them. A remote attacker who can supply crafted SpEL expressions can leverage this behavior to cause the application to exhaust its available resources and ultimately induce a DoS condition.

deeperData.description:
In Spring Framework versions 5.3.0 - 5.3.38 and older unsupported versions, it is possible for a user to provide a specially crafted Spring Expression Language (SpEL) expression that may cause a denial of service (DoS) condition.

Specifically, an application is vulnerable when the following is true:

  *  The application evaluates user-supplied SpEL expressions.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `spring-expression` package is vulnerable to a Denial of Service (DoS) attack. The `createArray()` method in the `ConstructorReference` class fails to validate if there are constructor resolvers available for arrays constructed from SpEL (Spring Expression Language) expressions. A remote attacker who can supply a SpEL expression can exploit this vulnerability to cause the system to proceed with potentially expensive operations and ultimately lead to a DoS condition.

***Advisory Deviation Notice***:
The Sonatype Security Research team discovered that this vulnerability was introduced in version 3.0.4.RELEASE and does not affect all earlier versions as stated in the advisory.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The Apache `commons-collections` packages are vulnerable to a Denial of Service (DoS) attack. The `add()` method of the `SetUniqueList` class mishandles the order of operations when invoking its parent `List` implementation. Consequently, adding an instance of itself results in infinite recursion and deviates from the behavior defined by the standard JRE `List` contract. A remote attacker who can cause an application to add `SetUniqueList` instances to themselves can exploit this vulnerability to crash the affected application with a `StackOverflowError` exception.

deeperData.description: JFreeChart v1.5.4 was discovered to be vulnerable to ArrayIndexOutOfBounds via the 'setSeriesNeedle(int index, int type)' method. NOTE: this is disputed by multiple third parties who believe there was not reasonable evidence to determine the existence of a vulnerability. The submission may have been based on a tool that is not sufficiently robust for vulnerability identification.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `org.jfree:jfreechart` package is vulnerable due to an Improper Validation of Array Index. The `setSeriesNeedle()` function in the `CompassPlot` class fails to validate that the given `index` falls within the bounds of the `seriesNeedle` array. This will result in an `ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException` which can be leveraged by an attacker to conduct a Denial of Service (DoS) attack.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using the `setSeriesNeedle()` function from this component with untrusted user input.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: There is no non-vulnerable upgrade path for this component/package. We recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.description: Jenkins 2.393 and earlier, LTS 2.375.3 and earlier uses the Apache Commons FileUpload library without specifying limits for the number of request parts introduced in version 1.5 for CVE-2023-24998 in org.kohsuke.stapler.RequestImpl, allowing attackers to trigger a denial of service.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The Jenkins `stapler` package is vulnerable to Denial of Service (DoS) attacks. The `parseMultipartFormData()` method in the `RequestImpl` class fails to limit the number of files permitted in a multipart upload forcing the application using `StaplerRequest` to process files, to consume excessive resources. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by uploading a large number of files in a single request. This will exhaust system resources and ultimately result in a DoS condition. 

*Advisory Deviation Notice:*
                        The Sonatype Security Research team has created a CVSS score that differs from the publicly available score that, based on our research, more accurately reflects the severity of the vulnerability.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.

In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.description: In Jenkins 2.423 and earlier, LTS 2.414.1 and earlier, processing file uploads using the Stapler web framework creates temporary files in the default system temporary directory with the default permissions for newly created files, potentially allowing attackers with access to the Jenkins controller file system to read and write the files before they are used.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `stapler` package is vulnerable due to the Creation of Temporary Files With Insecure Permissions. The `parseMultipartFormData()` method in the `RequestImpl` class creates a temporary directory to process file uploads with insecure default permissions. An attacker with access to the local file system can leverage this behavior to read and write to the file before it is used. Depending on how the system uses the affected file this can result in Information Disclosure, a Denial of Service (DoS) condition, or other unexpected behavior.

**Note:** The default permissions for newly created files generally only allow attackers to read the temporary file, but not write to it.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component with an operating system that uses a shared temporary directory for all users (typically Linux).
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue. IF upgrading is not a viable option, the project has provided the following [workaround](https://www.jenkins.io/security/advisory/2023-09-20/#SECURITY-3073):
>As a workaround, you can change your default temporary-file directory using the Java system property java.io.tmpdir.

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.description: In Spring Framework versions 5.3.0 - 5.3.18, 5.2.0 - 5.2.20, and older unsupported versions, the patterns for disallowedFields on a DataBinder are case sensitive which means a field is not effectively protected unless it is listed with both upper and lower case for the first character of the field, including upper and lower case for the first character of all nested fields within the property path.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `spring-context` package is vulnerable to Improper Handling of Case Sensitivity. The `setDisallowedFields()` and `isAllowed()` methods in the `DataBinder` class fail to ensure that string comparisons during the data binding validation phase are case insensitive. Attackers with control over input fields used to bind data to object attributes have the ability to bypass disallowed fields. This may alter the expected functionality of the application. This also requires attackers to know the details of the `disallowedFields` deny list.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown:
The application is vulnerable by using this component. The project maintainers provide some additional information regarding the conditions for this to be exploitable:

- Registration of disallowed field patterns in a DataBinder
- `spring-webmvc` or `spring-webflux` dependency
- The issue relates to data binding used to populate an object from request parameters (either query parameters or form data). Data binding is used for controller method parameters that are annotated with @ModelAttribute or optionally without it, and without any other Spring Web annotation.
- The issue does not relate to @RequestBody controller method parameters (e.g. JSON deserialization). However, such methods may still be vulnerable if they have another method parameter populated via data binding from query parameters.
- Your Spring MVC or Spring WebFlux application may be susceptible to data binding issues even if you do not register disallowed field patterns. We highly encourage you to review your DataBinder configuration and more broadly your approach to data binding. For more details, please see the new Data Binding Model Design section in the Spring Framework reference manual.

Reference: [https://spring.io/blog/2022/04/13/spring-framework-data-binding-rules-vulnerability-cve-2022-22968](https://spring.io/blog/2022/04/13/spring-framework-data-binding-rules-vulnerability-cve-2022-22968)
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control. 

Potential Mitigation:
```
our recommended approach is to use a dedicated model object that exposes only properties that are relevant for the supported use case. Another alternative is to switch to allowed field patterns: instead of supplying a "deny list" via setDisallowedFields(), you can supply an explicit "allow list" via setAllowedFields() in a WebDataBinder.
```
Reference: [https://spring.io/blog/2022/04/13/spring-framework-data-binding-rules-vulnerability-cve-2022-22968](https://spring.io/blog/2022/04/13/spring-framework-data-binding-rules-vulnerability-cve-2022-22968)

The `instantiate()` and `uninstantiate2()` methods in the `DescribableModel` class logs warning messages containing secrets passed as step parameters when the configuration of a build step fails. An attacker with access to the default system log can leverage this behavior to obtain secrets that may be used to perform further attacks against an affected application.

deeperData.description: Solr versions 1.3.0 to 1.4.1, 3.1.0 to 3.6.2 and 4.0.0 to 4.10.4 are vulnerable to an XML resource consumption attack (a.k.a. Lol Bomb) via it’s update handler.?By leveraging XML DOCTYPE and ENTITY type elements, the attacker can create a pattern that will expand when the server parses the XML causing OOMs.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `wstx-asl` package is vulnerable to XML Entity Expansion. The `ReaderConfig` class by default sets flags that allows and processes user controlled XML files with custom DTD and Entity elements. An attacker can exploit this behavior to cause a "billion laughs" style attack, resulting in a Denial of Service (DoS) situation.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: There is no non vulnerable version of this component/package. We recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `woodstox-core` package is vulnerable to Improper Restriction of  XML eXternal Entity (XXE) Reference. The `setFeature` and `getFeature` methods in `WstxSAXParserFactory.class` rely on the `mSecureProcessing` boolean value to be able to securely parse input XML. The boolean value, however, is set to `false` by default. Additionally, the class lacks support for properties `XMLConstants.FEATURE_SECURE_PROCESSING` and `XMLInputFactory.IS_SUPPORTING_EXTERNAL_ENTITIES`, which can make it possible for an attacker to conduct XXE attacks.

deeperData.description: Jenkins 2.470 and earlier, LTS 2.452.3 and earlier allows agent processes to read arbitrary files from the Jenkins controller file system by using the `ClassLoaderProxy#fetchJar` method in the Remoting library.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `org.jenkins-ci.main:remoting` package is vulnerable to Absolute Path Traversal attacks. The `preloadJar()` and `fetchJar()` methods in the `Channel` and `RemoteClassLoader$ClassLoaderProxy` classes respectively fail to properly restrict `Agents` from retrieving arbitrary files from `Controllers`. A remote attacker, in control of an agent, can exploit this vulnerability to read files and load code into controllers, potentially leading to Remote Code Execution (RCE).

deeperData.description: Jenkins JUnit Plugin 1166.va_436e268e972 and earlier does not escape test case class names in JavaScript expressions, resulting in a stored cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability exploitable by attackers able to control test case class names in the JUnit resources processed by the plugin.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The Jenkins `junit` plugin is vulnerable to Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks. The `failed-test.jelly` file fails to properly sanitize test case class names before rendering them. A remote attacker able to control the names of test classes provided as JUnit resources to the plugin can exploit this vulnerability with JUnit test class names that contain malicious JavaScript. This will result in script execution when the affected view is rendered by a victim's browser.

deeperData.description: A missing permission check in Jenkins Mailer Plugin 391.ve4a_38c1b_cf4b_ and earlier allows attackers with Overall/Read access to use the DNS used by the Jenkins instance to resolve an attacker-specified hostname.

deeperData.description: Jenkins Matrix Project Plugin 1.19 and earlier does not escape HTML metacharacters in node and label names, and label descriptions, resulting in a stored cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability exploitable by attackers with Agent/Configure permission.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `matrix-project` package is vulnerable to Cross-site Scripting (XSS) attacks. the `jsstr()` and `buildLabelCheckBox()` methods in the `LabelAxis$DescriptorImpl` class fail to treat HTML metacharacters as text inside of nodes, label names, and label descriptions. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability to bypass the current method of sanitization in order to store malicious JavaScript in Jenkins. This will result in script execution when an affected view that loads the stored result is rendered by a victim's browser.

deeperData.description: Jenkins Matrix Project Plugin 822.v01b_8c85d16d2 and earlier does not sanitize user-defined axis names of multi-configuration projects, allowing attackers with Item/Configure permission to create or replace any config.xml files on the Jenkins controller file system with content not controllable by the attackers.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:

The `MatrixProject` class does not properly validate user input when creating or replacing configuration files for multi-configuration projects in Jenkins. A remote attacker with Item/Configure permission to create or replace any `config.xml` files via the REST API endpoint can send a specially crafted `config.xml` file, including directory traversal characters in the Matrix axis name, to gain unauthorized access to sensitive information in the Jenkins instance.

deeperData.description: Pivotal Spring Framework through 5.3.16 suffers from a potential remote code execution (RCE) issue if used for Java deserialization of untrusted data. Depending on how the library is implemented within a product, this issue may or not occur, and authentication may be required. NOTE: the vendor's position is that untrusted data is not an intended use case. The product's behavior will not be changed because some users rely on deserialization of trusted data.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `org.springframework:spring-web` package is vulnerable to deserialization of untrusted data leading to Remote Code Execution (RCE). The `readRemoteInvocation()` method in `HttpInvokerServiceExporter.class` does not properly verify or restrict untrusted objects prior to deserializing them. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by sending malicious requests containing crafted objects, which when deserialized, execute arbitrary code on the vulnerable system.

*NOTE:* This vulnerability is related to a previously reported deserialization vulnerability (CVE-2011-2894) within the package, impacting a different class.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component under specific scenarios as listed out in the [advisory](https://www.tenable.com/security/research/tra-2016-20).
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

A warning has been provided in the official [Javadocs](https://docs.spring.io/spring-framework/docs/5.3.x/javadoc-api/org/springframework/remoting/httpinvoker/HttpInvokerServiceExporter.html) of the `HttpInvokerServiceExporter` class and support for several serialization-based remoting technologies including this class has been deprecated from 5.3.0 onwards and completely removed from 6.0.0 and onwards:

>WARNING: Be aware of vulnerabilities due to unsafe Java deserialization: Manipulated input streams could lead to unwanted code execution on the server during the deserialization step. As a consequence, do not expose HTTP invoker endpoints to untrusted clients but rather just between your own services. In general, we strongly recommend any other message format (e.g. JSON) instead.

The developer's general advice also states:
>Do not use Java serialization for external endpoints, in particular not for unauthorized ones. HTTP invoker is not a well-kept secret (or an "oversight") but rather the typical case of how a Spring application would expose serialization endpoints to begin with... he has a point that we should make this case all across our documentation, including the javadoc. But I don't really see a CVE case here, just a documentation improvement.
>
>Pivotal will enhance their documentation for the 4.2.6 and 3.2.17 releases.

Reference: [https://www.tenable.com/security/research/tra-2016-20](https://www.tenable.com/security/research/tra-2016-20)

deeperData.description: Applications that use UriComponentsBuilder to parse an externally provided URL (e.g. through a query parameter) AND perform validation checks on the host of the parsed URL may be vulnerable to a  open redirect https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/601.html  attack or to a SSRF attack if the URL is used after passing validation checks.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `spring-web` package is vulnerable due to Improper Input Validation. The `fromUriString()` method in the `UriComponentsBuilder` class fails to correctly validate URIs according to the [RFC 3986](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.2) specification, allowing input to mistake the `userinfo` part of the resource as a `hostname` part. Attackers with the ability to influence URIs validated by applications that utilize this library can exploit this vulnerability by crafting URIs that may result in open redirects, and under some circumstances, Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) attacks.


***Advisory Deviation Notice***:
The Sonatype Security Research team discovered that this vulnerability was actually introduced in version 3.0.0.RELEASE and does not exist in all versions prior to 5.3.32 as stated in the advisory.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.description:
Applications that use UriComponentsBuilder to parse an externally provided URL (e.g. through a query parameter) AND perform validation checks on the host of the parsed URL may be vulnerable to a  open redirect https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/601.html  attack or to a SSRF attack if the URL is used after passing validation checks.

This is the same as  CVE-2024-22259 https://spring.io/security/cve-2024-22259  and  CVE-2024-22243 https://spring.io/security/cve-2024-22243 , but with different input.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `spring-web` package is vulnerable due to Improper Input Validation. The `fromUriString()`, `fromOriginHeader()`, and `fromHttpUrl()` methods of the `UriComponentsBuilder` class use regular expressions to parse URLs into parts in a manner nonconformant to the [RFC 3986](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3986) standard. Consequently, certain character sequences may cause `UriComponentsBuilder` to yield unexpected results. A remote attacker who can provide a URL to be parsed by `UriComponentsBuilder` can leverage this behavior to circumvent validations of the parsed result which, depending on how the validated URL is used, may allow them to execute Open Redirect attacks, Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF), or other malicious actions.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown:
The application is vulnerable by using this component if it employs security-related validations dependent on the results of untrusted URLs parsed by `UriComponentsBuilder`.

Reference: <https://spring.io/security/cve-2024-22262>

deeperData.description:
Applications that parse ETags from "If-Match" or "If-None-Match" request headers are vulnerable to DoS attack.

Users of affected versions should upgrade to the corresponding fixed version.

Users of older, unsupported versions could enforce a size limit on "If-Match" and "If-None-Match" headers, e.g. through a Filter.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `org.springframework:spring-web` package is vulnerable to Regular expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attacks. The `HttpHeaders::getETagValuesAsList()` and `ServletWebRequest::matchRequestedETags()` methods fail to use a secure regular expression to parse "If-Match" and "If-None-Match" HTTP headers. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by submitting requests with specially crafted headers. This would consume excessive resources once processed by an affected application, potentially resulting in a DoS condition.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue. If this is not possible, enforce a size limit on "If-Match" and "If-None-Match" headers, e.g. through a `Filter`, as suggested in the advisory.

**Reference:** <https://spring.io/security/cve-2024-38809>

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.description: In spring security versions prior to 5.4.11+, 5.5.7+ , 5.6.4+ and older unsupported versions, RegexRequestMatcher can easily be misconfigured to be bypassed on some servlet containers. Applications using RegexRequestMatcher with `.` in the regular expression are possibly vulnerable to an authorization bypass.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `spring-security-web` package is vulnerable to Authorization Bypass. The `RegexRequestMatcher()` function in the `RegexRequestMatcher` class and the `addSecureUrl()` function in the `DefaultFilterInvocationSecurityMetadataSource` class can return an unexpected match when a `.` character is used in a regular expression. A remote attacker can exploit this behavior by supplying line terminating characters in their request to gain unauthorized access.

deeperData.description: Spring Security, versions 5.7 prior to 5.7.5 and 5.6 prior to 5.6.9 could be susceptible to authorization rules bypass via forward or include dispatcher types. Specifically, an application is vulnerable when all of the following are true: The application expects that Spring Security applies security to forward and include dispatcher types. The application uses the AuthorizationFilter either manually or via the authorizeHttpRequests() method. The application configures the FilterChainProxy to apply to forward and/or include requests (e.g. spring.security.filter.dispatcher-types = request, error, async, forward, include). The application may forward or include the request to a higher privilege-secured endpoint.The application configures Spring Security to apply to every dispatcher type via authorizeHttpRequests().shouldFilterAllDispatcherTypes(true)
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `spring-security-web` package is vulnerable to Authorization Bypass. The `doFilterInternal()` method in the `AuthorizationFilter` class fails to properly intercept all API requests that are forwarded with certain dispatcher types, leaving requests open to unauthorized abuse. An attacker with access to a service or application utilizing Spring's `AuthorizationFilter` to ensure requests are authorized may interact with the application to extract or modify sensitive application information without having been authenticated.

*Advisory Deviation Notice:*
                        The Sonatype Security Research team discovered that this vulnerability was actually introduced in version 5.5.0 instead of 5.6.0 as stated in the advisory.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown:
The application is vulnerable by using this component with the following conditions:

1. The application expects that Spring Security applies security to forward and include dispatcher types.
2. The application uses the `AuthorizationFilter` either manually or via the `authorizeHttpRequests()` method.
3. The application configures the `FilterChainProxy` to apply to forward and/or include requests (e.g. `spring.security.filter.dispatcher-types = request, error, async, forward, include`).
4. The application may forward or include the request to a higher privilege-secured endpoint.
The application configures Spring Security to apply to every dispatcher type via `authorizeHttpRequests().shouldFilterAllDispatcherTypes(true)`

Reference: [https://tanzu.vmware.com/security/cve-2022-31692](https://tanzu.vmware.com/security/cve-2022-31692)

deeperData.description: In Spring Security, versions 5.7.x prior to 5.7.8, versions 5.8.x prior to 5.8.3, and versions 6.0.x prior to 6.0.3, the logout support does not properly clean the security context if using serialized versions. Additionally, it is not possible to explicitly save an empty security context to the HttpSessionSecurityContextRepository. This vulnerability can keep users authenticated even after they performed logout. Users of affected versions should apply the following mitigation. 5.7.x users should upgrade to 5.7.8. 5.8.x users should upgrade to 5.8.3. 6.0.x users should upgrade to 6.0.3.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `spring-security-config` and `spring-security-web` packages are vulnerable to Insufficient Session Expiration. Multiple methods in multiple classes, stated below, fail to properly clean up the security context when serialized versions are in use. This flaw can keep leave users authenticated even after they have logged out, therefore putting their sessions and data at risk.

**Advisory Deviation Notice:** The Sonatype Security Research team has identified that Spring Security Config/Web versions prior to 5.7.0 may also be vulnerable to the flaw (i.e. when cases described in **Detection** not related to `HttpSessionSecurityContextRepository` apply) contrary to what is implied by the [advisory](https://spring.io/security/cve-2023-20862).

*Vulnerable File(s) and Function(s)*:

org/springframework/security/config/annotation/web/configurers/LogoutConfigurer.class
- createLogoutFilter()

createLogoutFilter()org/springframework/security/web/authentication/logout/SecurityContextLogoutHandler.class
- logout()
- setClearAuthentication()

org/springframework/security/web/context/HttpSessionSecurityContextRepository.class
- saveContext()
deeperData.detectionMarkdown:
The application is vulnerable by using this component when **any** of the following applies:

- You are using the `SecurityContextHolderFilter` or `requireExplicitSave(true)` and you are using Spring Security's logout support with serialized sessions (e.g. Spring Session) and `invalidateHttpSession(false)`
- You are logging users out manually by saving an empty `SecurityContext` into the `HttpSessionSecurityContextRepository`
- You have a custom `SecurityContextRepository` that does not rely on the `HttpSession`

You are **not** vulnerable if **any** of the following applies:
- You are still using the deprecated `SecurityContextPersistenceFilter` or `requireExplicitSave(false)`
- You are using Spring Security's logout support with in-memory sessions.
- You are not saving an empty `SecurityContext` into the `HttpSessionSecurityContextRepository`

[Source](https://spring.io/security/cve-2023-20862)

deeperData.description:
Using "**" as a pattern in Spring Security configuration 
for WebFlux creates a mismatch in pattern matching between Spring 
Security and Spring WebFlux, and the potential for a security bypass.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `spring-security-config` and `spring-security-web` packages are vulnerable due to Improper Access Control. The `pathMatchers()` methods of the `AbstractServerWebExchangeMatcherRegistry` class and the constructor of the `PathPatternParserServerWebExchangeMatcher` class mishandle request mapping for unprefixed double-wildcard (`**`) patterns. Consequently, and due to discrepancies between Spring WebFlux and Spring Security's pattern-matching behavior, mappings may be broader than expected in scope. A remote attacker can abuse this behavior in affected applications with requests for resources or functionality that would otherwise be restricted.

*Advisory Deviation Notice*: The Sonatype security research team discovered that this vulnerability was introduced in version `5.0.0.M2` and not `5.6.0` as stated in the advisory.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown:
The application is vulnerable by using this component in combination with Spring Security if Spring Security's request matcher is configured to use unprefixed double-wildcard (`**`) patterns.

Reference: <https://spring.io/security/cve-2023-34034>
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. deeperData.description:
In Spring Security, versions 5.7.x prior to 5.7.12, 5.8.x prior to 
5.8.11, versions 6.0.x prior to 6.0.9, versions 6.1.x prior to 6.1.8, 
versions 6.2.x prior to 6.2.3, an application is possible vulnerable to 
broken access control when it directly uses the AuthenticatedVoter#vote passing a null Authentication parameter.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `spring-security-core` package is vulnerable due to Weak Authentication. The `isFullyAuthenticated()` method from the `AuthenticatedVoter` class does not properly validate the `authentication` parameter when authenticating a user. When a vulnerable application sets the aforementioned parameter to null and calls `AuthenticatedVoter#vote`, the method returns `true`, allowing an attacker to bypass the authentication process and gain access to otherwise restricted information.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown:
The application is vulnerable by using this component only when the following conditions are met:

>The application uses AuthenticatedVoter directly and a null authentication parameter is passed to it resulting in an erroneous true return value.

Reference: [https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-f3jh-qvm4-mg39](https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-f3jh-qvm4-mg39)
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue. Alternatively, since AuthenticatedVoter is deprecated from 5.8, AuthorizationManager should be used as a replacement according to the [advisory](https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-f3jh-qvm4-mg39)

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. deeperData.description: A vulnerability in sshd-core of Apache Mina SSHD allows an attacker to overflow the server causing an OutOfMemory error. This issue affects the SFTP and port forwarding features of Apache Mina SSHD version 2.0.0 and later versions. It was addressed in Apache Mina SSHD 2.7.0
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The Apache `sshd-core` package is vulnerable to a Denial of Service (DoS) attack. The `writeBuffer()` and `startWriting()` methods in the `BufferedIoOutputStream` class use a boundless buffer to store data from write requests. Additionally, since the methods do not reject extraneous write requests, they allow data to accumulate infinitely until read by a client. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by inducing numerous write requests in order to cause the application to consume all available memory, resulting in a DoS condition.

*Advisory Deviation Notice*: The Sonatype security research team discovered that this vulnerability was introduced in version 0.12.0 and not 2.0.0 as stated in the advisory.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown:
The application is vulnerable by using the SFTP and port forwarding features provided by this component.

Reference: [https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/red01829efa2a8c893c4baff4f23c9312bd938543a9b8658e172b853b@%3Cannounce.apache.org%3E](https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/red01829efa2a8c893c4baff4f23c9312bd938543a9b8658e172b853b@%3Cannounce.apache.org%3E)

deeperData.description: Class org.apache.sshd.server.keyprovider.SimpleGeneratorHostKeyProvider in Apache MINA SSHD <= 2.9.1 uses Java deserialization to load a serialized java.security.PrivateKey. The class is one of several implementations that an implementor using Apache MINA SSHD can choose for loading the host keys of an SSH server.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `sshd-common` package is vulnerable to Deserialization of Untrusted Data. The `doReadKeyPairs()` method in the `SimpleGeneratorHostKeyProvider` class allows user-controlled SSH key pairs to be deserialized without limiting the types of Java object that may be provided. An attacker with the ability to submit key pairs may craft a malicious serialized payload containing code that can eventually be executed on the application server, resulting in Arbitrary Code execution.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

Mitigation:

```
For Apache MINA SSHD <= 2.9.1, do not use 
org.apache.sshd.server.keyprovider.SimpleGeneratorHostKeyProvider to generate 
and later load your server's host key. Use separately generated host key files, 
for instance in OpenSSH format, and load them via a 
org.apache.sshd.common.keyprovider.FileKeyPairProvider instead. Or use a custom 
implementation instead of SimpleGeneratorHostKeyProvider that uses the OpenSSH 
format for storing and loading the host key (via classes 
OpenSSHKeyPairResourceWriter and OpenSSHKeyPairResourceParser).
```
Reference: [https://www.mail-archive.com/dev@mina.apache.org/msg39312.html](https://www.mail-archive.com/dev@mina.apache.org/msg39312.html)

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.description:
Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor vulnerability in Apache Software Foundation Apache MINA.

In SFTP servers implemented using Apache MINA SSHD that use a RootedFileSystem, logged users may be able to discover "exists/does not exist" information about items outside the rooted tree via paths including parent navigation ("..") beyond the root, or involving symlinks.

This issue affects Apache MINA: from 1.0 before 2.10. Users are recommended to upgrade to 2.10
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The Apache `sshd-common` and `sshd-sftp` packages are vulnerable to Information Disclosure attacks. The methods and classes listed below fail to account for symlinks and certain traversal character sequences in user-requested paths. Consequently, applications using a `RootedFileSystem` may disclose information regarding the existence of files outside of the root directory. A remote attacker with permission to perform `RootedFileSystem` operations can exploit this behavior to uncover information about the underlying file system. The information obtained may be leveraged to perform further attacks against affected applications.

*Advisory Deviation Notice:*
                        The Sonatype Security Research team has created a CVSS score that differs from the publicly available score that, based on our research, more accurately reflects the severity of the vulnerability.

*Vulnerable File(s) and Function(s)*:

org/apache/sshd/common/file/root/RootedFileSystemProvider.class
- protected void createLink(Path link, Path target, boolean symLink, FileAttribute<?>... attrs)
- protected Path root(RootedFileSystem rfs, Path nat)
- protected Path resolveLocalPath(RootedPath path)

org/apache/sshd/sftp/client/fs/SftpFileSystemProvider.class
- public void copy(Path source, Path target, CopyOption... options)
- public void move(Path source, Path target, CopyOption... options)

org/apache/sshd/sftp/server/AbstractSftpSubsystemHelper.class
- protected Map<String, Object> doStat(int id, String path, int flags)
- protected void doRealPath(Buffer buffer, int id)
- protected SimpleImmutableEntry<Path, Boolean> validateRealPath(int id, String path, Path f, LinkOption... options)
- protected void doRemoveDirectory(int id, String path, boolean followLinks)
- protected void doMakeDirectory(int id, String path, Map<String, ?> attrs, boolean followLinks)
- protected void doRemoveFile(int id, String path, boolean followLinks)
- protected NavigableMap<String, Object> resolveFileAttributes(Path path, int flags, LinkOption... options)

org/apache/sshd/sftp/server/SftpSubsystem.class
- protected void doReadDir(Buffer buffer, int id)
- protected String doOpenDir(int id, String path, Path dir, LinkOption... options)
deeperData.detectionMarkdown:
The application is vulnerable by using this component if operating as an SFTP server with a [`RootedFileSystem`](https://javadoc.io/static/org.apache.sshd/sshd-common/2.9.2/org/apache/sshd/common/file/root/RootedFileSystem.html).

Reference: <https://lists.apache.org/thread/b9qgtqvhnvgfpn0w1gz918p21p53tqk2>

deeperData.description:
Like many other SSH implementations, Apache MINA SSHD suffered from the issue that is more widely known as CVE-2023-48795. An attacker that can intercept traffic between client and server could drop certain packets from the stream, potentially causing client and server to consequently end up with a connection for which 
some security features have been downgraded or disabled, aka a Terrapin 
attack

The mitigations to prevent this type of attack were implemented in Apache MINA SSHD 2.12.0, both client and server side. Users are recommended to upgrade to at least this version. Note that both the client and the server implementation must have mitigations applied against this issue, otherwise the connection may still be affected.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `org.apache.sshd:sshd-core` package is vulnerable to Improper Validation of Integrity Check Value ("SSH Terrapin" Attack). The `doHandleMessage()` method of the `AbstractSession` establishes SSH connections without accounting for the authenticity and sequence numbers of the handshake. An attacker can exploit this flaw by downgrading the security of the SSH connection, potentially allowing Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks and drop packets between the client and the server, ultimately disrupting the communication.

deeperData.description:
Apache Commons FileUpload before 1.5 does not limit the number of request parts to be processed resulting in the possibility of an attacker triggering a DoS with a malicious upload or series of uploads.




Note that, like all of the file upload limits, the
          new configuration option (FileUploadBase#setFileCountMax) is not
          enabled by default and must be explicitly configured.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The Apache Commons FileUpload `commons-fileupload` package and the `tomcat-coyote` package are vulnerable to Denial of Service (DoS) attacks. The `parseRequest` function in the `FileUploadBase.class` file in each package does not enforce a maximum number of files that can be included in a single upload request. An attacker can exploit this flaw to potentially trigger an application crash or slowdowns, resulting in DoS.

*Advisory Deviation Notice:*
                        The Sonatype Security Research team discovered that this vulnerability was actually introduced in version 7.0.0 of `tomcat-coyote` instead of 8.5.0 as stated in the advisory. In addition, it was found that this vulnerability affected the 10.x branch of `tomcat-coyote` from 10.0.0-M1 and not 10.1.0-M1 as stated in the advisory.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `trilead-ssh2` package is vulnerable to Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks. This project downloads dependencies over HTTP due to an insecure repository configuration within the `.pom` file. Consequently, a MitM could intercept requests to the specified repository and replace the requested dependencies with malicious versions, which can execute arbitrary code from the application that was built with them.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `codemirror` package is vulnerable to a Regular expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attack. The `footnoteUrl()` function in the `markdown.js` file uses an unsafe regular expression to parse link titles from footnotes within user-supplied markdown. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by supplying markdown that leverages a long string of repeating `\` characters to cause catastrophic backtracking and ultimately a DoS condition.
